Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery kylix; broken at top at turn of lip; interior: once glazed (fired reddish brown); exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal procession: winged creature (possibly bird or siren) to right with only traces of black remaining; band below and top of second frieze with two tendrils or perhaps animal tails.
Curator's comments: Venit identifies the sherd as an aryballos but since it is glazed black on its interior, it must be an open vessel (Venit 1982, 67, no. A54) .
Possibly froom same cup as 1924,1201.1173. The sherd has a lower shoulder than the cup 1924,1201.1174 etc.
Bibliographic references: Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no. 3)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 67, no. A54) (Identified as an aryballos)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.097) (Phase 1)
